awd_titl_txt: High Fidelity Numerical Investigations of Tailored Magnetic Fields for Defect Reduction in Continuous Casting of Steel
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funding for the investigation of strategies to improve the quality of continuous-cast steel by applying tailored magnetic fields to alter fluid flow in the mold region to reduce the formation of defects. Magnetic fields apply additional forces to the steel flow which change the velocities that affect the transport of inclusions and level fluctuations that produce most of the defects in the current process. To accomplish this, high-fidelity computer models will be developed based on accurate modeling of the turbulence and its interactions with the magnetic fields. Advanced parallel computers based on graphics processing units will be used to reduce the computational times and increase the mesh resolution. The computer models developed will be applied to study flow fields in model and industrial geometries to characterize the effects of different magnetic field configurations. The ultimate objective is to obtain the most desirable configuration for performance and practical viability.

If successful, the project will reduce defects and reduce the waste of energy, material and resources during the continuous-casting of steel, a process which is used to produce over 90 percent of the steel in the United States and globally. The principal investigators have close interactions with several steel producers through the Continuous Casting Consortium at the University of Illinois which provides an industry perspective as well as the means to implement results into practice. The research is expected to contribute to the fundamental understanding of turbulent flows in complex domains subjected to varied magnetic field configurations. The use of graphics processing units for fluid flow simulations has recently enabled significant advantages in speed and accuracy and this work will also be extended to clusters of multiple graphics processing units.

por.por_cntn:
Continuous casting of steel is an important manufacturing process used by all steel producing industries throughout the world. Reducing the defects in this process is of major economic benefit. In the research project funded by the National Science Foundation, the investigators conducted accurate numerical simulations of the flow and inclusion transport in this process and studied the effects of magnetic fields, nozzle submergence depth on flow characteristics and inclusion transport. A high-performance computational model using the parallel computing power of Graphics Processing Units (GPU) was developed as a part of this support. The key outcomes of this project are as follows.

Intellectual Merits
CUFLOW, a powerful code for solving three-dimensional transient fluid flow and heat transfer problems was developed and implemented on GPU. Several modules including a large eddy simulation (LES) module, a generalized Newtonian fluid module, a magnetohydrodynamics module, a volume of fluid module and two way coupled Lagrangian particle tracking module were implemented into CUFLOW and were parallelized onto multiple GPUs. The multi-GPU version of CUFLOW has been tested and used to study flow problems related to continuous casting of steel. The code was written in a universal way to exploit full performance of multicore computers and demonstrated on the Blue Waters supercomputer at the University of Illinois.
 
The CUFLOW code was then applied to study multiphase turbulent flow in steel continuous casting with applied magnetic fields. Specifically, the effects of single ruler and double ruler configurations, submergence depth, casting speed were investigated through accurate time-dependent computations. The numerical results revealed complex vertical recirculation regions that influence the transport and capture of the inclusions. The effects of the magnetic fields were to alter these flow fields, stabilize the unsteadiness and dampen the turbulence. These were accurately predicted by present simulations, as validated by comparison with lab-scale physical models, and with plant measurements.

Broader Impacts
Results of the many different aspects of this study were presented at the annual meetings of the Continuous Casting Consortium (CCC) at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The research methodology, results, and practical implications were presented to and discussed with several industry members of the consortium including. Recommendations to improve the plant operations were made. For example, parametric studies suggest that nozzle submergence should be adjusted to avoid centering the magnetic field directly across the nozzle ports.  Some of these suggestions have already been implemented in plant (e.g. turning off the magnetic braking system when casting at low casting speeds, in order to avoid meniscus freezing and associated particle entrapment defects). 

Relevant findings of this work have been incorporated and presented at the annual Brimacombe Continuous Casting Courses (one week short course attended by over a 100 continuous casting practitioners) every summer. The knowledge and findings obtained from this work were distributed to these practitioners in the steel industry. The use of single and multiple GPUs to accelerate computations were also presented as a tutorial to conference attendees of the 2014 ASME Fluids Engineering Summer Meeting (Chicago, IL, USA) through a GPU programming short course. Example codes and materials were given to the audience to help them learn GPU coding.
